ğŸ”¢ Channels

Frequencies are divided into channels.

  • 2.4GHz = 11 channels (but only 1, 6, 11 are non-overlapping in U.S.)
  • 5GHz = 23+ channels, mostly non-overlapping

ğŸ§  Tip: Channel overlap causes signal interference. Use non-overlapping channels in shared buildings.

ğŸ”µ Bluetooth

Short-range wireless (~10 meters). Used for headsets, file transfer, keyboard/mouse.

ğŸ§  Uses 2.4GHz and frequency hopping to avoid interference

ğŸ§  Tip: Know which support dual-band (n, ax), and which are 5GHz-only (a, ac)

ğŸ“ Long-Range Fixed Wireless

  • Licensed: Must register with regulators (FCC in U.S.), less interference
  • Unlicensed: Open to public (e.g., 2.4GHz), more interference

Power: Limited by lawâ€”too much = fines
Regulatory Requirements: Ensure proper use of spectrum, avoid interference

ğŸ§  Tip: Used in rural areas, campus buildings, or point-to-point setups

ğŸ“² NFC (Near-Field Communication)

Ultra short-range (â‰¤4 cm). Used for tap-to-pay, ID badges, transit cards. Works by inductive coupling.

ğŸ§  Tip: Compare to Bluetooth: NFC is faster to connect but works at a much shorter range.

ğŸ“» RFID (Radio-Frequency Identification)

Uses radio waves to identify tags or devices. Common in:

  • Inventory tracking
  • Toll tags
  • Access cards

ğŸ§  Tip: Passive RFID = no battery, powered by reader. Active RFID = has its own power source

  • 2.4GHz = long range, slow, interference
